factoid: Rostov noticed that Denisov did not like to be reminded of the regiment.
Denisov did not like to be reminded of the free life outside the hospital.
Denisov seemed to try to forget his old life.
Denisov was only interested in the affair with the commissariat officers.
When Rostov inquired about how the matter stood, Denisov produced a paper he had received from the commission.
Denisov had a rough draft of his answer to the commission.
Denisov became animated when he began reading his paper.
Denisov drew Rostov's attention to the stinging rejoinders he made to his enemies.
Rostov's hospital companions gathered around him, a fresh arrival from outside.
The companions gradually dispersed as soon as Denisov began reading his answer.
Rostov noticed by their faces that all those gentlemen had already heard that story more than once and were tired of it.
The man who had the next bed, a stout Uhlan, continued to sit on his bed, gloomily frowning and smoking a pipe.
The one-armed Túshin still listened, shaking his head disapprovingly.
In the middle of the reading, the Uhlan interrupted Denisov.
The Uhlan said that it would be best simply to petition the Emperor for pardon.
The Uhlan said that great rewards would now be distributed, and surely a pardon would be granted.
Denisov exclaimed that he would petition the Emperor.
Denisov tried hard to give the old energy and fire, but sounded like an expression of irritable impotence.
Denisov said that if he were a wobber he would ask mercy, but he was being court-martialed for bringing wobbers to book.
Denisov said that he was not afraid of anyone.
Denisov said that he had served the Tsar and his country honorably and had not stolen.
Denisov asked whether he was to be degraded.
Denisov said that he was writing to them straight.
Denisov said that if he had wobbed the Tweasuwy.
Túshin said that the writing was certainly well written.
Túshin said that the point was not the writing but that one has to submit.
Túshin said that Vasili Dmtrich did not want to submit.
Túshin said that the auditor told them it was a bad business.
Denisov said that it was certainly bad.
Túshin said that the auditor had written out a petition for Denisov.
Túshin said that Denisov ought to sign the petition and ask Rostov to take it.
Túshin said that Rostov had connections on the staff.
Túshin said that there was no better opportunity.
Denisov interrupted Túshin and went on reading his paper.
Rostov did not have the courage to persuade Denisov.
Rostov instinctively felt that the way advised by Túshin and the other officers was the safest.
Rostov would have been glad to be of service to Denisov.
Rostov knew Denisov's stubborn will and straightforward hasty temper.
The reading of Denisov’s virulent reply took more than an hour.
After the reading, Rostov said nothing.
Rostov spent the rest of the day in a dejected state of mind amid Denisov’s hospital comrades.
Denisov was moodily silent all evening.
Late in the evening, when Rostov was about to leave, Rostov asked Denisov whether he had no commission for him.
Denisov said yes and told Rostov to wait a bit.
Denisov glanced round at the officers.
Denisov took his papers from under his pillow.
Denisov went to the window.
Denisov had an inkpot at the window.
Denisov sat down to write.
Denisov said that it seemed no use knocking one’s head against a wall.
Denisov gave Rostov a large envelope.
The envelope contained the petition to the Emperor drawn up by the auditor.
Denisov, without alluding to the offenses of the commissariat officials, simply asked for pardon.
Denisov handed the petition in.
Denisov gave a painfully unnatural smile.
Rostov returned to the regiment and told the commander the state of Denisov’s affairs.
Rostov rode to Tilsit with the letter to the Emperor.
